Idiom (Asturian): Nun dar un palu al agua
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Negative verb phrase with prepositional clause; fixed structure
Figurative Meaning: To be lazy or avoid any kind of work or effort
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common across Asturias, likely linked to fishing culture where 'palu' (pole) refers to work
First Example Sentence: ¡Mira esi rapaz! ¡Nun da un palu al agua dende que nació!
Second Example Sentence: Si sigues ensin dar un palu al agua, nun vas algamar nada.
Third Example Sentence: Dixen d'él qu’en tol branu nun dio un palu al agua.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Infinitive phrase with definite article and adjective; fixed clause
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Similar to Spanish idiom; reflects Mediterranean bureaucratic culture
First Example Sentence: El profesor fizo la vista gorda cola copia.
Second Example Sentence: Na empresa suel facese la vista gorda coles hores extra.
Third Example Sentence: Fiz la vista gorda porque entendí la so situación.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Comparative phrase with noun clause; fixed structure
Figurative Meaning: To exaggerate or invent stories excessively
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: References Saturnino Calleja, famed Spanish publisher of children’s tales
First Example Sentence: Tien más cuento que Calleja, nun-y creas nada.
Second Example Sentence: Cuando empieza falar, ya sabes que tien más cuento que Calleja.
Third Example Sentence: Pintólo como una traxedia, pero ye que tien más cuento que Calleja.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Infinitive phrase with verb-noun construction; fixed idiomatic verb phrase
Figurative Meaning: Things are going badly or the situation is deteriorating
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to Spanish card game suits; bastos represent difficulty
First Example Sentence: Si gana esi partíu, va pintar bastos pa toos.
Second Example Sentence: Colos precios como tán, pinta bastos na economía.
Third Example Sentence: Cuando salieron les encuestes, empezó a pintar bastos.

Figurative Meaning: To go around talking nonsense or boasting foolishly
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Falar ensin sentíu o presumiendo de más
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Local legend from Llibardón, parody of self-important musician
First Example Sentence: Anda por ahí como’l gaiteru de Llibardón, ensin saber de qué fala.
Second Example Sentence: Cada vez que lo mires, va como’l gaiteru de Llibardón.
Third Example Sentence: Falaba tanto qu’acabó como’l gaiteru de Llibardón: ensin público.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Infinitive verb phrase with prepositional clause; vulgar, idiomatic structure
Figurative Meaning: To speak nonsense or without thinking
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common across informal Asturian speech; matches earthy humor traditions
First Example Sentence: Deja de falar pol culu y diz algo sensatu.
Second Example Sentence: Taba tan cansáu que falaba pol culu ensin parar.
Third Example Sentence: Falen pol culu, como si nun tuvieran neurones.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Verb phrase with negation and noun; fixed clause
Figurative Meaning: To be completely broke, without money
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: ‘Blanca’ was a low-value coin in old Spain, also used metaphorically
First Example Sentence: Esti mes toy ensin blanca, tengo que ahorrar.
Second Example Sentence: Siempre ta ensin blanca a final de mes.
Third Example Sentence: Nun pudimos salir porque tábamos ensin blanca.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Reflexive verb phrase with prepositional clause; fixed metaphorical structure
Figurative Meaning: To avoid a direct answer or change the subject
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Based on geometry—‘tanxente’ means tangent, used metaphorically
First Example Sentence: Cuando-y preguntaron, salió pela tanxente enseguida.
Second Example Sentence: Tien l'arte de salise pela tanxente y nun responder a na.
Third Example Sentence: Siempre que hai problemes, salse pela tanxente.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Copulative phrase with definite noun; emphatic expression
Figurative Meaning: To be the best, the most impressive (or, ironically, the worst)
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Possibly euphemism of stronger vulgar word; popular in Asturian youth speech
First Example Sentence: Esa fiesta fue la repanocha, de verdá.
Second Example Sentence: ¡La repanocha de trabayu que me mandaron!
Third Example Sentence: Nun-y valía con poco, quería la repanocha.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Verb phrase with simile; regional idiomatic use
Figurative Meaning: To end up looking ridiculous or naive
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Quedar como un inocente o ridículu
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: ‘Paisanu’ refers to rural person; reflects urban-rural dynamics in speech
First Example Sentence: Nun me dixesti nada y quedé como un paisanu.
Second Example Sentence: Metí la pata y quedé como un paisanu del to.
Third Example Sentence: Cola sorpresa que-y dieron, quedó como un paisanu.
